@realmoney Apr 24, 2020 | 01:25 PM EDT DOUG KASS S&P Levels in a Glance * A summary of my near term (three months) expectations It has often been said that a good forecaster is not smarter than everyone else, he merely has his ignorance better organized. Here are my

expectations for the S&P Index over the next several months: * S&P cash currently stands at 2810. * My "fair market value" calculation is 2800 on the S&P Inde - 18x 2022 S&P EPSe of $155/share. (Don't think precision!) * I don't expect anything near a retest of the March lows.

(In short form, my reasons are: the level of interest rate levels, a likely flattening in the curve, the size of the Fed's bazooka, generally bearish market positioning and my confidence in the scientific and health communities). * However, I do have growing concerns about the

Administration's ability to successfully manage (and "get to work") the aforementioned fiscal bazooka ("helicopter money") as well as providing a consistent and efficacious policy towards a national "reopening" that has the potential of pushing us back into the spread of Covid-19

On the latter point, it is my strong view that our nation's response to coronavirus has been a deadly mix of arrogance and incompetence. These factors have the potential to be the next market "stories" -- pushing stocks toward the lower end of my expected range. (More on that

@Revshark This morning you have tweeted five times about my views on @realdonaldtrump - responding in generalities about my emotional "garbage" expressed in my 2020 @realdonaldtrump "No Apologies Tour" I have never responded in kind to your political opinions - I have tried to

have respectful debate about your market views which I find to be value added. For some reason you are obsessed. I would note that well known financial commentators like @jimcramer @ScottWapnerCNBC @riskreversal @andrewrsorkin and many more frequently express their political

opinions on Twitter and elsewhere. Of course my opinions are immersed in my Twitter feeds but I defy you to find someone else in the financial community that is as comprehensive in my remarks. I believe in free speech - I thought you did as a Libertarian. Were you to tweet out

your political views or if you tweeted about the weather - I would respect that and though I am at the polar opposite politically I would never be as abusive as you have been. In the past I have blocked you for this. I wont block you but I will no longer respond
(and defend myself) against what seems like an obsession. This has become a distraction and, like you, have alot of business obligations during the day. Trade well - I know you will. Be safe,
Then focus on the market. And lose your obsession - its boring me and others.

You always respond in generalities rather than specifics. Did Trump not suggest the possibility of injecting disinfectant or introducing UV inside one's body? Did Azar not appoint a labradoodle breeder to run the Covid-19 effort? PS We all have political bias, we both do.

If you want to have a bonafide and respectful discussion I would be happy to. Otherwise just stop reading my Twitter thread. You accuse me frequently of having TDS (Trump Derangement Syndrome). I am beginning to feel you have DDS (Dougie Derangement Syndrome) @revshark

of civil service jobs. As Professor Richardson explains, Trump has appointed Michael Rigas to head the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). Rigas believes that the 1883 Civil Service Act is unconstitutional because it requires that civil service jobs be non-partisan.

Rigas “wants to get rid of that system and make all employees of the executive branch political appointees, loyal not to the country but to Trump.” Yesterday I mentioned that Trump transferred Dr. Richard Bright from an important position in the CDC for refusing to approve

indiscriminate use of hydroxychloroquine. Trump transferred Bright, but could not fire him because of the Civil Service Act. Bright is a civil servant, not a political appointee who serves at the pleasure of the president. Professor Richardson also notes that Health and Human

Services Secretary Azar has appointed an aide to manage HHS’s response to the pandemic. Before taking charge of HHS’s pandemic response, the aide “was a dog breeder who specialized in Labradoodles” for the six year period ending 2018.
